figure_1.title: Fig. 1. Flowchart of study inclusion for the bibliometric analysis.

figure_2.title: Fig. 2. Articles published annually on mycobacterium tuberculosis infection between 1979 and 2017 and based in Korea, by research area.

figure_3.title: Fig. 3. Percentage of articles by study design in basic research and clinical research. The most common study design was biochemistry in basic research (A) and cross-sectional study in clinical research (B).

figure_4.title: Fig. 4. Five-year impact factor of journals in which articles on tuberculosis and by researchers based in Korea were published between 1979 and 2017.

claims.sentence: Ultimately, 1,101 articles were included in the present analysis (Fig. 1).

Notably, the number of articles dealing with diagnostics or treatment of TB increased significantly and rapidly (CAGR = 15.3%; P < 0.001) while the number of articles on vaccines and on operational and public health, increased relatively slowly (CAGR = 2.8%; P = 0.011) (Fig. 2).
Among the former, biochemistry was the most common theme (146/383; 38.1%) (Table 1 and Fig. 3A).
Among clinical research, cross-sectional studies were most common (149/682; 21.8%) (Fig. 3B).

The two most-cited articles were: 1) a basic research with 380 citation times which revealed the fundamental mechanism on antimycobacterial defenses19 and 2) a clinical study with 324 citations on accuracy of interferon-gamma release assay for the diagnosis of latent TB infection.20 As the number of total published articles increased, the number of those published in journals with high 5-year impact factors also increased (Fig. 4).
Ultimately, 1,101 articles were included in the present analysis (Fig. 1).

Notably, the number of articles dealing with diagnostics or treatment of TB increased significantly and rapidly (CAGR = 15.3%; P < 0.001) while the number of articles on vaccines and on operational and public health, increased relatively slowly (CAGR = 2.8%; P = 0.011) (Fig. 2).
Among the former, biochemistry was the most common theme (146/383; 38.1%) (Table 1 and Fig. 3A).
Among clinical research, cross-sectional studies were most common (149/682; 21.8%) (Fig. 3B).

The two most-cited articles were: 1) a basic research with 380 citation times which revealed the fundamental mechanism on antimycobacterial defenses19 and 2) a clinical study with 324 citations on accuracy of interferon-gamma release assay for the diagnosis of latent TB infection.20 As the number of total published articles increased, the number of those published in journals with high 5-year impact factors also increased (Fig. 4).
Ultimately, 1,101 articles were included in the present analysis (Fig. 1).
